questions.text: The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) primarily describes the body's response to which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a model developed by Hans Selye that describes the body's physiological response to stress. It outlines how the body responds to any demand (stressor) placed upon it, regardless of whether the stressor is physical, psychological, or environmental. The GAS consists of three stages: alarm reaction (fight-or-flight response), resistance (adaptation), and exhaustion. It represents a general biological response to stress rather than being specific to any particular psychiatric condition.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect) : While panic attacks involve physiological stress responses, they represent a specific type of anxiety response rather than the general stress response described by GAS. Panic attacks are acute episodes characterized by intense fear and specific physical symptoms like palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath. Option B. Depression (Incorrect) : Depression represents a mood disorder with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and other emotional and physical symptoms. While chronic stress can contribute to depression, and there may be HPA axis dysregulation in depression, GAS describes the general stress response rather than the specific pathophysiology of depression. Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect) : Anxiety disorders involve excessive worry, fear, and physiological arousal. While anxiety certainly involves stress response systems, GAS describes the broader physiological response to any stressor, not just anxiety disorders.
  • • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect) : While panic attacks involve physiological stress responses, they represent a specific type of anxiety response rather than the general stress response described by GAS. Panic attacks are acute episodes characterized by intense fear and specific physical symptoms like palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath.
  • • Option A. Panic Attacks (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Depression (Incorrect) : Depression represents a mood disorder with persistent low mood, anhedonia, and other emotional and physical symptoms. While chronic stress can contribute to depression, and there may be HPA axis dysregulation in depression, GAS describes the general stress response rather than the specific pathophysiology of depression.
  • • Option B. Depression (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect) : Anxiety disorders involve excessive worry, fear, and physiological arousal. While anxiety certainly involves stress response systems, GAS describes the broader physiological response to any stressor, not just anxiety disorders.
  • • Option C. Anxiety Disorders (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) is a fundamental model describing how the body responds physiologically to any type of stressor through three stages: alarm reaction, resistance, and exhaustion. It involves the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and represents a non-specific response to stress rather than being particular to any specific psychiatric condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an endocrine change associated with protein-energy malnutrition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the body undergoes specific hormonal adaptations to conserve energy and maintain essential functions. Cortisol, being a stress hormone, actually increases in malnutrition (not decreases). This elevated cortisol helps mobilize amino acids from muscle tissue, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver, and maintains blood glucose levels during nutritional stress—all critical survival mechanisms during starvation.
  • • The theory of adaptation in malnutrition explains these hormonal changes as the body's attempt to prioritize vital functions while reducing energy expenditure on growth and other non-essential processes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Low insulin - CORRECT finding in PEM. Insulin secretion decreases to minimize glucose uptake by peripheral tissues and maintain blood glucose for brain function.
  • • Option A. Low insulin
  • • Option C. Low thyroid hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) decrease, resulting in reduced basal metabolic rate and oxygen consumption as an energy-sparing adaptation.
  • • Option C. Low thyroid hormone
  • • Option D. Elevated growth hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Despite increased growth hormone levels, there is peripheral resistance to its action and decreased production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), explaining the growth failure despite high GH levels.
  • • Option D. Elevated growth hormone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Protein-energy malnutrition produces a characteristic endocrine profile with elevated stress hormones (cortisol), decreased anabolic hormones (insulin, thyroid hormones), and elevated but ineffective growth hormone—all serving to conserve energy and maintain vital functions during nutritional deprivation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy involved in drug abuse reports experiencing cross-over of sensory perceptions, where he describes that sounds can be seen and colors can be heard. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The phenomenon described is synesthesia (reflex hallucinations), where stimulation in one sensory modality leads to experiences in another sensory modality (e.g., "seeing" sounds or "hearing" colors). This effect is most commonly associated with hallucinogens, particularly LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect) : Cocaine is a stimulant that primarily causes sympathetic activation (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis) and euphoria. While cocaine can cause psychotic symptoms like paranoia and tactile hallucinations ("cocaine bugs" or formication), it does not typically cause synesthesia or sensory crossover effects. Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect) : While cannabis (marijuana) can also cause synaesthesia or reflex hallucinations, between cannabis & LSD, LSD remains the better answer as these perceptual disturbances are the characteristic feature of hallucinogen intoxication. Option D. PCP (Incorrect) : Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, detachment from reality, and severe behavioral disturbances. While it can cause various perceptual disturbances, the specific cross-sensory phenomenon of synesthesia is more characteristic of classical hallucinogens like LSD.
  • • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect) : Cocaine is a stimulant that primarily causes sympathetic activation (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis) and euphoria. While cocaine can cause psychotic symptoms like paranoia and tactile hallucinations ("cocaine bugs" or formication), it does not typically cause synesthesia or sensory crossover effects.
  • • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect) : While cannabis (marijuana) can also cause synaesthesia or reflex hallucinations, between cannabis & LSD, LSD remains the better answer as these perceptual disturbances are the characteristic feature of hallucinogen intoxication.
  • • Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect)
  • • Option D. PCP (Incorrect) : Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, detachment from reality, and severe behavioral disturbances. While it can cause various perceptual disturbances, the specific cross-sensory phenomenon of synesthesia is more characteristic of classical hallucinogens like LSD.
  • • Option D. PCP (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Synesthesia (the crossing or merging of sensory modalities) is a characteristic effect of hallucinogenic drugs, particularly LSD. This perceptual phenomenon, where stimuli in one sensory domain trigger experiences in another (like seeing sounds or tasting colors), is part of the profound alterations in consciousness that make LSD and similar substances powerful hallucinogens.

questions.text: A woman compulsively washes her hands at least 40 times per day without any logical reason. Which of the following Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) techniques is most appropriate for her treatment? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Response Prevention is the most appropriate technique for treating compulsive hand washing, which is a classic symptom of OCD. In this case, the woman engages in repetitive handwashing (compulsion) likely in response to obsessive thoughts about contamination. Response Prevention involves preventing the person from performing the compulsive behavior (handwashing) when they feel the urge. This breaks the reinforcement cycle where the anxiety reduction from performing the compulsion reinforces the behavior. When used together with Exposure therapy, it forms "Exposure and Response Prevention" (ERP), which is the first-line psychotherapeutic treatment for OCD.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Exposure (Incorrect) : While Exposure is an important component of treating OCD, it is typically used in conjunction with Response Prevention. Exposure alone (having the patient confront the feared contaminant) without preventing the compulsive response would not effectively treat the condition as the patient would continue to use handwashing to reduce anxiety. Hence, if we have to pick between exposure and response prevention, the response prevention becomes the better answer. Option C. Thought Stopping (Incorrect) : Thought stopping is a technique where the patient attempts to interrupt unwanted thoughts, often using distraction or verbal commands. While sometimes used in cognitive therapy, it's not considered highly effective for OCD treatment and is not the first-line approach for compulsive behaviors. Option D. Desensitization (Incorrect) : Systematic desensitization involves gradually exposing patients to anxiety-provoking stimuli while they are in a relaxed state. While useful for specific phobias, it is not the primary technique for treating compulsive behaviors in OCD. The technique doesn't address the response component of the OCD cycle.
  • • Option B. Exposure (Incorrect) : While Exposure is an important component of treating OCD, it is typically used in conjunction with Response Prevention. Exposure alone (having the patient confront the feared contaminant) without preventing the compulsive response would not effectively treat the condition as the patient would continue to use handwashing to reduce anxiety. Hence, if we have to pick between exposure and response prevention, the response prevention becomes the better answer.
  • • Option B. Exposure (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Thought Stopping (Incorrect) : Thought stopping is a technique where the patient attempts to interrupt unwanted thoughts, often using distraction or verbal commands. While sometimes used in cognitive therapy, it's not considered highly effective for OCD treatment and is not the first-line approach for compulsive behaviors.
  • • Option C. Thought Stopping (Incorrect)
  • • Option D. Desensitization (Incorrect) : Systematic desensitization involves gradually exposing patients to anxiety-provoking stimuli while they are in a relaxed state. While useful for specific phobias, it is not the primary technique for treating compulsive behaviors in OCD. The technique doesn't address the response component of the OCD cycle.
  • • Option D. Desensitization (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the treatment of choice for OCD, including compulsive hand washing. Response Prevention specifically targets the compulsive behavior by preventing the ritualistic response, while Exposure targets the obsessional fears. Together they break the OCD cycle of obsessions leading to anxiety, followed by compulsions that temporarily reduce anxiety but ultimately reinforce the behavior.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fulvestrant is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist, also known as a Selective Estrogen Receptor Down-regulator (SERD). Unlike SERMs, fulvestrant has no agonist activity in any tissue. It binds to estrogen receptors and causes their degradation, preventing estrogen receptor dimerization so that ER interaction with DNA is prevented. The ER is thus down-regulated, resulting in complete suppression of estrogen-responsive gene function.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Raloxifene - This is incorrect. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that exhibits tissue-selective effects. It acts as an estrogen receptor agonist in bone (increasing bone formation and preventing osteoporosis) and blood vessels (improving lipid profile), but acts as an antagonist in breast and endometrial tissues. Option B. Tamoxifen - This is incorrect. Tamoxifen is also a SERM with mixed agonist and antagonist effects. It acts as an antagonist in breast tissue (making it useful for breast cancer treatment) but has estrogenic effects on the endometrium, which can increase the risk of endometrial proliferation and cancer. Option D. Clomiphene - This is incorrect. Clomiphene is a SERM that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in the pituitary, which blocks estrogenic feedback inhibition of gonadotropin secretion. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating ovulation. It's used to treat anovulatory infertility.
  • • Option A. Raloxifene - This is incorrect. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that exhibits tissue-selective effects. It acts as an estrogen receptor agonist in bone (increasing bone formation and preventing osteoporosis) and blood vessels (improving lipid profile), but acts as an antagonist in breast and endometrial tissues.
  • • Option A. Raloxifene
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen - This is incorrect. Tamoxifen is also a SERM with mixed agonist and antagonist effects. It acts as an antagonist in breast tissue (making it useful for breast cancer treatment) but has estrogenic effects on the endometrium, which can increase the risk of endometrial proliferation and cancer.
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen
  • • Option D. Clomiphene - This is incorrect. Clomiphene is a SERM that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in the pituitary, which blocks estrogenic feedback inhibition of gonadotropin secretion. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating ovulation. It's used to treat anovulatory infertility.
  • • Option D. Clomiphene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fulvestrant is distinct from SERMs (like raloxifene, tamoxifen, and clomiphene) in that it is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist with no agonist activity in any tissue, allowing it to be effective in cases of tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of drug dependence? (NEET PG 2016)

options.label: C
options.text: Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Use of illegal substances is not a diagnostic feature of drug dependence. Drug dependence is defined by specific psychological and physiological features related to substance use patterns and their effects, regardless of whether the substance is legal or illegal. Dependence can develop to legal substances (such as alcohol, prescription medications) just as it can to illegal substances.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect) : Tolerance is a core feature of drug dependence, defined as "increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect." As the body adapts to the presence of the substance, more is needed to achieve the same psychoactive effects, which is a hallmark sign of dependence. Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect) : A persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use is a recognized feature of dependence. This represents the loss of control aspect of addiction, where individuals recognize the problems caused by their substance use but struggle to stop despite their intentions. Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect) : Taking the substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended is a characteristic feature of dependence. This reflects the impaired control over substance use that defines dependence.
  • • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect) : Tolerance is a core feature of drug dependence, defined as "increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect." As the body adapts to the presence of the substance, more is needed to achieve the same psychoactive effects, which is a hallmark sign of dependence.
  • • Option A. Tolerance (Incorrect)
  • • Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect) : A persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use is a recognized feature of dependence. This represents the loss of control aspect of addiction, where individuals recognize the problems caused by their substance use but struggle to stop despite their intentions.
  • • Option B. Persistent desire to quit drug (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect) : Taking the substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended is a characteristic feature of dependence. This reflects the impaired control over substance use that defines dependence.
  • • Option C. Consumption of large amounts of drug over a prolonged period (Incorrect)

  • ➤ Tolerance- Increasing amounts of a substance are required to get the desired effect Withdrawal symptoms: Typical symptoms that develop when the substance intake is reduced or stopped. Option D. Magic Mushrooms (Incorrect) : Magic mushrooms contain psilocybin, a hallucinogen that can cause short-term psychotic-like experiences during intoxication. questions.text: All of the following are true about Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), except: (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Increased intracranial pressure is an absolute contraindication for ECT.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased intracranial pressure is an absolute contraindication for ECT.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to current understanding, there are no absolute contraindications for ECT.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT (Correct) : Osteoporosis is indeed a relative contraindication for ECT because the muscle contractions during the seizure could potentially cause fractures in patients with severe osteoporosis. However, with modern modified ECT using muscle relaxants, this risk is significantly reduced. Option B. Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT (Correct) : Benzodiazepines should be discontinued before ECT because they have anticonvulsant properties that can raise the seizure threshold and potentially interfere with the therapeutic efficacy of ECT by reducing seizure duration. Option C. The most common complication is Amnesia (Correct) : Memory disturbances, particularly retrograde amnesia, are the most common side effects of ECT. Retrograde amnesia is more common than anterograde amnesia, and recovery typically occurs within 1-6 months.
  • • Option A. Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT (Correct) : Osteoporosis is indeed a relative contraindication for ECT because the muscle contractions during the seizure could potentially cause fractures in patients with severe osteoporosis. However, with modern modified ECT using muscle relaxants, this risk is significantly reduced.
  • • Option A. Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT (Correct)
  • • Option B. Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT (Correct) : Benzodiazepines should be discontinued before ECT because they have anticonvulsant properties that can raise the seizure threshold and potentially interfere with the therapeutic efficacy of ECT by reducing seizure duration.
  • • Option B. Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT (Correct)
  • • Option C. The most common complication is Amnesia (Correct) : Memory disturbances, particularly retrograde amnesia, are the most common side effects of ECT. Retrograde amnesia is more common than anterograde amnesia, and recovery typically occurs within 1-6 months.
  • • Option C. The most common complication is Amnesia (Correct)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While ECT requires careful consideration of patient-specific factors, there are no absolute contraindications for its use. Earlier, raised intracranial pressure was considered an absolute contraindication for ECT, but no longer. The main side effect is memory disturbance, particularly retrograde amnesia, which is usually temporary. Modern modified ECT using anaesthesia and muscle relaxants has significantly improved the safety profile of this effective treatment for severe depression, catatonia, and certain other psychiatric conditions.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Agoraphobia is specifically defined as fear of places from which escape might be difficult. The fear of heights (acrophobia) is a specific phobia and not a component of agoraphobia. Agoraphobia includes fears related to situations where escape might be challenging, embarrassing, or help may not be available if panic-like symptoms occur.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect) : This is the core definition of agoraphobia. People with agoraphobia fear situations where they feel trapped, helpless, or embarrassed. Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect) : This is included in the definition of agoraphobia. Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect) : Fear of crowded places is a characteristic manifestation of agoraphobia. Crowded places may trigger anxiety due to perceived difficulty in escaping or reaching help if needed.
  • • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect) : This is the core definition of agoraphobia. People with agoraphobia fear situations where they feel trapped, helpless, or embarrassed.
  • • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect)
  • • Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect) : This is included in the definition of agoraphobia.
  • • Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect)
  • • Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect) : Fear of crowded places is a characteristic manifestation of agoraphobia. Crowded places may trigger anxiety due to perceived difficulty in escaping or reaching help if needed.
  • • Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Agoraphobia is characterized by fear of situations where escape might be difficult, help might not be available, or where panic attacks might occur. It commonly includes fears of open spaces, enclosed places, crowds, public transportation, and being outside alone. Specific phobias like acrophobia (fear of heights) are distinct from agoraphobia and classified separately as specific phobias.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.correct_answer: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.
  • • The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.
  • • Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more
  • • Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.
  • • Option B. 10 or more skin pustules
  • • Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.
  • • Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.
